author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Economic Demands Test Biden Even Before Inauguration
description: With the recovery slowing and coronavirus cases surging, Democrats must decide whether quick action on federal aid is more important than its scale.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s first economic test is coming months before Inauguration Day, as a slowing recovery and accelerating coronavirus infections give new urgency to talks on government aid to struggling households and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As a G.O.P. Playbook on Voter Fraud Falls Flat, Some Ask: What’s Next?
description: In dozens of lawsuits, Republicans tried to make voting and counting votes harder. After a record turnout and a Democratic presidential win, some wonder if that’s the party’s best strategy.
content: WASHINGTON — It was an election where Republican charges of fictitious voter fraud took center stage before, during and after the count, backed by a barrage of lawsuits intent on making it harder to cast or tally votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Woman Is Stabbed, and Two 15-Year-Olds Are Charged With Murder
description: Nyla Bond, 20, became friendly with one of the teenagers last year. Now she is dead, and questions swirl around the motive for the killing.
content: Nyla Bond, 20, met Anmerie Morales, 15, about a year ago. Despite their age difference, they became friends and often spent time together at the Bronx apartment where Ms. Bond lived with her mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Eric Schmitt, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Al Qaeda’s No. 2, Accused in U.S. Embassy Attacks, Was Killed in Iran
description: Israeli agents shot Abu Muhammad al-Masri on the streets of Tehran at the behest of the U.S., officials said, but no one — Iran, Al Qaeda, the U.S. or Israel — has publicly acknowledged the killing.
content: WASHINGTON — Al Qaeda’s second-highest leader, accused of being one of the masterminds of the deadly 1998 attacks on American embassies in Africa, was killed in Iran three months ago, intelligence officials have confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: Partial Owners of Washington’s N.F.L. Team Seek Path in Court to Sell Their Stake
description: Three limited partners said in a federal court filing that Daniel Snyder, the team’s majority owner, was trying to block the sale of their combined 40 percent stake for $900 million.
content: The increasingly bitter battle for control of the Washington Football Team took a significant turn on Friday when three of the team’s limited partners, who together own 40 percent of the club, asked a federal judge to allow them to sell their shares as a group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Biden Asked Republicans to Give Him a Chance. They’re Not Interested.
description: Joe Biden promised not only to win, but to “restore the soul of the nation.” But the deep divisions that animated President Trump’s tenure show no signs of receding.
content: MASON, Texas — The change at the Sunday prayer service was so subtle it went unnoticed by several congregants. Tucked in between calls for divine health and wisdom, the Rev. Fred Krebs of St. Paul Lutheran Church, who rarely brings up politics, fleetingly mentioned this month’s presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: This Coronavirus Surge Does Not Have to Be So Horrific
description: America is entering a difficult period. But the outcome is not foregone.
content: In the spring, when the coronavirus was spreading across the planet, Americans took steps — slow and uneven as they might have been — to bring the first U.S. outbreaks under control. Houses of worship and nonessential businesses closed. People resigned themselves to wearing masks in public. They worked from home if they could, to reduce the risk to those who could not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Lynn Kellogg, who found the spotlight in ‘Hair,’ dies at 77.
description: Lynn Kellogg Simpers, a singer and actress who, as Lynn Kellogg, played Sheila, the uptight debutante who turns into a free-spirited hippie in the original 1968 Broadway production of “Hair,” died on Thursday in St. Louis. She was 77.
content: Lynn Kellogg Simpers, a singer and actress who, as Lynn Kellogg, played Sheila, the uptight debutante who turns into a free-spirited hippie in the original 1968 Broadway production of “Hair,” died on Thursday in St. Louis. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: It Took a Century to Open a Mosque in Athens. Then Came the Pandemic.
description: The first purpose-built Muslim place of worship in the Greek capital since the Ottoman occupation arrived after decades of delay — just in time for a second coronavirus surge.
content: ATHENS — The mosque that took more than a century to open, surviving legal, political and financial challenges, has closed in less than a week, a temporary victim of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sridhar Pappu
title: Savannah Guthrie Is Feeling Lucky
description: Since she held President Trump’s feet to the fire at a crucial turning point of the campaign, her future at NBC News appears bright.
content: “Nobody’s sorry to see someone say something nice,” said Savannah Guthrie, the 48-year-old co-host of the “Today” show. “But I also see people say things that aren’t nice. I try not to let any of it in. It’s not reality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: How a Human Rights Angel Lost Her Halo
description: Ten years after she left house arrest and vowed to fight for justice, Myanmar’s civilian leader has instead become a jailer of critics and an apologist for the slaughter of minorities.
content: When Daw Aung San Suu Kyi emerged from years of house arrest a decade ago, having never used a smartphone or Facebook, she held court in the office of her banned political party, the smell of damp emanating from the human rights reports piled on the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, J. David Goodman and Julie Bosman
title: ‘It’s Traumatizing’: Coronavirus Deaths Are Climbing Once Again
description: Deaths are far below the rate of the spring, when as many as 2,200 people were dying every day, but experts warn they are rising fast.
content: By the time Doug Raysby’s wife was allowed to enter his hospital room, it was too late to be sure whether he even knew she was there. After a feverish fight with the coronavirus, he lay unconscious on the bed. His wife cried through an N95 mask, while a computer tablet flashed a video stream of his children saying goodbye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: A Girl Raised in Isolation Stumbles on an Exit
description: “Cleo Porter and the Body Electric,” a lighthearted adventure written before the pandemic, imagines a post-virus world eerily like the one we now inhabit.
content: CLEO PORTER AND THE BODY ELECTRICBy Jake Burt
source.name: The New York Times

title: Variety: Jelly Roll
description: Eric Berlin returns with another sweet and twisted new venture.
content: JELLY ROLL — As far as I can tell, this is Eric Berlin’s second new variety creation for us in 2020, another example of his gift of weaving sets of entries together in interesting ways. This puzzle looks like a spiral, but instead of solving two sets of clues in two directions, you solve everything reading from the outside of the spiral in. In that respect, it’s easier and less confusing, but there’s an additional layer of intricacy that makes it a nice challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Giuliani adds fuel to discredited theories about voting machines.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, continued on Saturday his effort to delegitimize votes cast through electronic voting machines, citing several conspiracies connected to the companies that make the machines and the software they run in a post on Twitter.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, continued on Saturday his effort to delegitimize votes cast through electronic voting machines, citing several conspiracies connected to the companies that make the machines and the software they run in a post on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Au Revoir but Not Adieu
description: For 12 years as a columnist I wore my “heart out after the unattainable.”
content: When I was a younger man, a quarter-century ago, I clambered into the armored Land Rover provided by this newspaper to cover the Bosnian war. It was, at the best of times, an unbalanced vehicle. At the worst, it would shudder as if possessed. I was headed from Sarajevo back to Paris to see my third child born. There was no other way home. The airport, under fire from Serbian artillery, was closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Goodbye, Golden Goose
description: Time for Donald Trump to head down Sunset Boulevard.
content: WASHINGTON — Many see a wannabe despot barricaded in the bunker, stubby fingers clinging to the levers of power as words that mean nothing to him — democracy, electoral integrity, peaceful transition, constitutionality — swirl above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Lee Hyo-jae, Champion of Women’s Rights in South Korea, Dies at 95
description: Ms. Lee was a prominent activist and a founder of women’s studies programs. She also stood up to the country’s dictators.
content: When Lee Hyo-jae learned of a university colleague’s research into the Korean “comfort women” who were taken by the Japanese military for use as sex slaves during World War II, she came to view them as victims of one of history’s most brutal war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Mr. President, Pack Your Bags and Be Gone
description: Trump wants to preserve, protect and defend only himself.
content: The ruler broods, alone with his rage and shame, undone by rejection, his mind, like Macbeth’s, “full of scorpions,” plotting to overturn facts and destroy American democracy. His lackeys, and only they remain, try to humor the master in his labyrinth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Pandemic Is Showing Us How Capitalism Is Amazing, and Inadequate
description: Why big business needs big government and vice versa.
content: The bananas news cycle of November 2020 included a fascinating public spat that is essential for understanding modern capitalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rome Tracks Down the Man Behind All That Graffiti. No, It’s Not Banksy.
description: The tagger known as Geco is not as famous as the British provocateur, but he has made a name for himself in Italy.
content: ROME — The post on the Rome mayor’s Facebook page was triumphant: The police had tracked down a man “once considered uncatchable,” she said in announcing that after a yearlong investigation, the authorities had discovered the real identity of the elusive tagger known only as Geco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Sainted Too Soon? Vatican Report Cast John Paul II in Harsh New Light
description: The former pope was fast-tracked for canonization immediately after his death. But a tarnished legacy in dealing with the church’s sex abuse scandals has left critics to wonder whether it was too fast.
content: ROME — At the funeral of Pope John Paul II at St. Peter’s Square, banners rose from the sea of mourners reading “Santo Subito,” or “Saint at Once.” He was a giant of the church in the 20th century, spanning the globe, inspiring generations of believers with his youthful magnetism, then aged infirmity, and, as the Polish pope, he helped bring down Communism over his more than 26-year reign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: When the White House Was Full of Claws, Scales, Stripes and Tails
description: The long tradition of presidential pets is set to resume this January with two German shepherds belonging to President-elect Joe Biden. Their predecessors weren’t always cats and dogs.
content: Residents of the White House have had fur and feathers, claws and hooves, scales, stripes and prehensile tails. Some were found on the property, many came with the new tenants and others were delivered by foreign leaders. But for most of modern U.S. history, the president has had a pet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Séamas O'Reilly
title: Watching the U.S. Election While Irish
description: “John King is back on shift!” gasped my sister Caoimhe. “It must be close.”
content: LONDON — As the polls closed on Election Day in America, my family group chat thrummed with anticipation. Maps were shared. Probabilities mocked. We argued over exit polls, safe seats and swing votes, breaking off occasionally to ask what, precisely, the Electoral College was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Woohae Cho
title: ‘Yogurt Ladies’ of South Korea Deliver More Than Dairy
description: They were among the country’s first women to work outside the home, helping establish South Korea’s taste for dairy products. And these beloved “yakult ajummas” are still making their rounds.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — An hour before dawn, Kang Hye-jeong was already ​out cruising on her battery-run mobile refrigerator, briskly moving through alleys in Cheongdam-dong, a district of southern Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Denies That Al Qaeda Leader Was Killed in Tehran
description: The denial came in the wake of a New York Times report that quoted intelligence officials as saying the terror group’s No. 2 leader was killed on the street in Tehran in August.
content: Iran’s Foreign Ministry on Saturday denied a report that Israeli agents had fatally shot Al Qaeda’s second-ranking leader on the streets of Tehran, likening it to a “Hollywood” scenario manufactured by “American and Zionist” officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Gurwitch
title: The Coronavirus Saved My Life
description: If I hadn’t gone in for a test, I wouldn’t have learned I had stage four metastatic lung cancer. I guess that’s a perverse kind of luck.
content: LOS ANGELES — This summer, I walked into an urgent care clinic for a coronavirus test and walked out with stage four metastatic lung cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Theme Shmeme
description: Caitlin Reid just couldn’t stay away, on a Sunday.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Caitlin Reid, it’s been too long! That’s right — we had a collaboration just last weekend, with Evan Kalish and a theme; you know, a regular Sunday. Now, Ms. Reid is solo, no net, no nothing — just a ton of crisp, interesting cluing, long entries and some great debuts in a big open grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Western Sahara Independence Group Ends Truce With Morocco
description: One of Africa’s longest-simmering conflicts erupts back into the open.
content: CAIRO — The leader of a pro-independence group in Western Sahara declared war Saturday on Morocco, shattering a three-decade-long cease-fire and threatening a full-blown military conflict in the disputed desert territory in northwest Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Christopher Krebs Hasn’t Been Fired, Yet
description: Mr. Krebs’s government agency contradicted President Trump’s false claims that the election was rigged. At this point, Mr. Krebs, a former Microsoft executive, still has a job.
content: WASHINGTON — Christopher Krebs is a 43-year-old former Microsoft executive who had the unenviable government job of protecting the nation’s election machinery from manipulation by Russia or other foreign hackers. It turns out, though, that some of the most dangerous interference has come not from the Kremlin but from the White House, where the president called the election “rigged” before a single vote was cast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Detroit’s Famous Lemon-Glazed Poundcake
description: Double the glaze.
content: This weekend make Otis Lee’s poundcake, adapted by CC Allen, from Mr. Fofo’s Deli in Detroit (above), Melissa Clark’s pumpkin sticky toffee puddings for two or Aaron Hutcherson’s brussels sprouts with honey and miso. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Shaw
title: Razzle Dazzle, Part 2: Broadway Triumphs Again
description: Michael Riedel’s “Singular Sensation” tracks the blockbuster successes of the 1990s.
content: SINGULAR SENSATION The Triumph of BroadwayBy Michael Riedel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Do I Really Have to Quarantine if I Visit Family for Thanksgiving?
description: Indoor gatherings with family and friends are still considered a high-risk activity, but there are ways to reduce your quarantine time.
content: Q: I’m planning to visit family in Arlington, Va., over Thanksgiving. It’s a nonstop drive, and I’ll be staying with relatives who have been very careful. Do I really need to quarantine when I return to my Manhattan co-op? I can’t imagine it’s any riskier than having dinner with family in Brooklyn or New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Sheila Kaplan
title: Missing From State Plans to Distribute the Coronavirus Vaccine: Money to Do It
description: The government has sent billions to drug companies to develop a coronavirus shot but a tiny fraction of that to localities for training, record-keeping and other costs for vaccinating citizens.
content: With the prospect that a coronavirus vaccine will become available for emergency use as soon as next month, states and cities are warning that distributing the shots to an anxious public could be hindered by inadequate technology, severe funding shortfalls and a lack of trained personnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Implores Trump to Confront a Surging Pandemic
description: President Trump broke his near-total silence on the coronavirus on Friday with an appearance in the Rose Garden in which he threatened to deny New York access to a vaccine.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. demanded on Friday that President Trump do more to confront the coronavirus infections exploding across the country, calling the federal response “woefully lacking” even as Mr. Trump broke a 10-day silence on the pandemic to threaten to withhold a vaccine from New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Lack of Fans at the Masters Strains Those Who Would Sell the Experience
description: Passes to the Masters are some of the most expensive tickets in sports. But with fans barred from Augusta National Golf Club and other venues this year, many resellers are under pressure.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For about two decades, James DiZoglio has run a bazaar to sell some of the most cherished tickets in sports. His scalping locale has always been the same: near the TBonz Steakhouse and the Augusta Best Inn down the street from the site of the Masters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Coleman Flowers
title: Mold, Possums and Pools of Sewage: No One Should Have to Live Like This
description: Before she died of Covid-19, Pamela Rush opened her home to show the world what poverty looks like.
content: My story starts in Lowndes County, Ala., a place that’s been called Bloody Lowndes because of its violent, racist history. It’s part of Alabama’s Black Belt, a broad strip of rich, dark soil worked and inhabited largely by poor Black people who, like me, are descendants of slaves. Our ancestors were ripped from their homes and brought here to pick the cotton that thrived in the fertile earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Iota, Now a Hurricane, Is Season’s 30th Named Storm
description: A Category One storm, Iota was expected to strengthen into a major hurricane by Monday as it approached the coast of Central America, according to the National Hurricane Center.
content: Tropical Storm Iota strengthened into a hurricane early Sunday as it continued to carve a path through the Caribbean Sea, days after becoming the 30th named storm in the record-breaking 2020 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Jannat Batra
title: Examine Ballot. Recite Name. Sort Into Bin. Repeat 5 Million Times.
description: A hand recount got underway in Georgia on Friday, with hundreds of poll workers rechecking ballots in a state that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. won by about 14,000 votes.
content: MARIETTA, Ga. — By the time President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. was declared the winner of Georgia’s 16 electoral votes on Friday afternoon, hundreds of county poll workers across the state were several hours into the arduous slog of recounting nearly five million ballots by hand.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Baseball First: A Woman Rises to Run a Team
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 14, 2020.
content: “When I got into this business, it seemed unlikely a woman would lead a major league team, but I am dogged in the pursuit of my goals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Crespino
title: What Democrats Are Up Against in Georgia
description: The Senate contenders face not just Republicans but also the state’s political history, which shows that change doesn’t come easy.
content: We are all Georgians now. Or at least that’s how it feels with the eyes of the nation focused on Georgia and its two U.S. Senate runoff elections on Jan. 5, which will determine party control of the Senate. Raphael Warnock, a Democrat, will face off against the Republican Senator Kelly Loeffler, and Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, will attempt to unseat the Republican Senator David Perdue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: ‘You Cannot Say No’: The Reign of Terror That Sustains Belarus’s Leader
description: Despite hundreds of thousands protesting against him for months, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko has been able to cling to power thanks to an all-pervasive security system.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Appalled by savage police violence at the start of Belarus’s would-be revolution, the host of a popular morning show on state television quit his job in protest and declared that his country’s veteran leader, no matter how brutal, would never “force Belarusians back into the box they existed in for these 26 years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Work to Defy History in Georgia Runoffs That Have Favored G.O.P.
description: The special elections were devised by white lawmakers to dilute the power of Black voters. But those involved in earlier contests say demographic change and Democratic energy could allow the party to finally beat the odds.
content: WASHINGTON — A first-term senator in Georgia narrowly bested his opponent, outrunning his party’s standard-bearer only to face voters again a few weeks later under a quirky system that briefly made the state the center of the political universe after a hard-fought presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Rory McIlroy Aims for Balance, and a Green Jacket
description: McIlroy, still seeking a Masters win for a career Grand Slam, struggled in the first round at Augusta National but rebounded in the second.
content: Rory McIlroy watched the flight of his ball in dismay on Friday morning. “That’s so bad,” he said. “Oh my God.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: As if We Didn’t Have Enough to Worry About …
description: Trump shuffles the Pentagon leadership, raising anxieties more.
content: A presidential transition can be a perilous time in the world. That’s particularly true when the departing president denies that he is departing and fires America’s top defense officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Joanna Harcourt-Smith, 74, Dies; Lived a ‘Psychedelic Love Story’
description: For an adventurous globe-trotting time, she was by the side of the LSD guru Timothy Leary, only to be left traumatized by the experience.
content: Joanna Harcourt-Smith was a 26-year-old European socialite in Switzerland in 1972 when she met Timothy Leary, the psychedelic Pied Piper to the flower children of the 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Sabrina Tavernise, Zach Montague, Allyson Waller and Maggie Haberman
title: Thousands rally in Washington as clashes erupt.
description: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.
content: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Time to Take a Pledge: No Stocks if You’re a Member of Congress
description: Owning actively traded shares can create conflicts of interest. Georgia’s Senate candidates agree. Will others? Mutual funds could be good for them.
content: The nation’s balance of power is at stake as both senators from Georgia face runoff elections in early January. The campaigns have been bitter, and they stand to get more so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Loses String of Election Lawsuits, Leaving Few Vehicles to Fight His Defeat
description: The president’s efforts to use the courts to delay or block President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory were turned aside in cases in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Arizona.
content: President Trump suffered multiple legal setbacks in three key swing states on Friday, choking off many of his last-ditch efforts to use the courts to delay or block President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Trump Is Not Doing Well With His Election Lawsuits. Here’s a Rundown.
description: The president has suffered a string of defeats in pursuing legal action seeking to delay certification of his loss to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: It is difficult to overturn an American election result, as President Trump has been reminded over and over again in the past few weeks. His campaign and his allies lost in courts and dropped cases in every battleground state where they filed them — Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Judges have been unpersuaded by “strained legal arguments without merit and speculative accusations,” as a federal judge in Pennsylvania wrote in the latest blistering ruling against the campaign on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau’s Ball Search Pushes Him Out of Masters Hunt
description: After predictions that he would dominate Augusta National, DeChambeau had a meltdown on the third hole Friday that put him below the projected cut line with six holes of his second round left to finish on Saturday morning.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was almost a given that Bryson DeChambeau would do something memorable at this year’s Masters tournament. It did not figure to be a booming tee shot so high in the Georgia sky that it landed clear out of sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: To Celebrate Diwali Is to Celebrate the Light
description: Diwali is a celebration of light. It reminds me that we can help one another get through the darkest times. And it comes at an especially grim time in our country.
content: Diwali became my American holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hayley Krischer
title: Leggings Take a Victory Lap
description: Everyone is still wearing leggings during the pandemic, including Kamala Harris.
content: When Vice President-elect Kamala Harris called to congratulate Joseph R. Biden Jr. on winning the election last Saturday, she was wearing what women everywhere in the United States seem to be wearing during the pandemic: leggings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
title: Federal Prosecutors Push Back on Barr Memo on Voter Fraud Claims
description: The prosecutors, assigned to monitor this month’s elections, said they had found no evidence to back any “substantial allegations” of voting irregularities.
content: WASHINGTON — Career Justice Department prosecutors pushed back this week against a memo by Attorney General William P. Barr that opened the door to politically charged election fraud investigations, saying in a pair of messages that Mr. Barr thrust the department into politics and falsely overstated the threat of voter fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Doug Mills and Bill Pennington
title: Without Augusta’s Famed Roars, the Masters Goes Quiet
description: The swell of the tournament’s spectators has long provided a dramatic soundtrack to the Masters’ most memorable finishes. In its absence, golfers will play their final rounds a cappella.
content: The swell of the tournament’s spectators has long provided a dramatic soundtrack to the Masters’ most memorable finishes. In its absence, golfers will play their final rounds a cappella.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: Trump Waves to Supporters Protesting Election Results
description: Demonstrators gathered in Washington on Saturday, echoing President Trump’s unfounded claims of election fraud. He waved to some of them from his motorcade as he was en route to his private golf club in Virginia.
content: Demonstrators gathered in Washington on Saturday, echoing President Trump’s unfounded claims of election fraud. He waved to some of them from his motorcade as he was en route to his private golf club in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 14, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about contenders for the cabinet of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. misstated one of Michael J. Morell’s past government positions. He is a former C.I.A. analyst, not a former Foreign Service officer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Divided Country: What Can Be Done?
description: Readers criticize Democrats for being too “woke” and not communicating their ideas better, urge a pardon of the president, suggest separation into two different countries, and more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Twittertorium
description: A reader suggests an alternative to the traditional presidential library.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
